title: Man injured at WestConnex site
text:
A construction worker was trapped under a concrete bar for close to an hour after accident at a WestConnex demolition site. February 21, 2017 1:23pm CareFlight paramedics pick up a man who was seriously injured on a construction site in St Peters Jillian McKee and Jim O’Rourke Inner West Courier Inner City Share Share on Twitter 
A man was trapped for almost an hour after a concrete bar fell onto his legs at a WestConnex demolition site yesterday afternoon.NSW Ambulance were called to the demolition site at Burrows Rd around 3.40pm after reports a male had suffered a serious leg injury.The 30-year-old man was trapped under the large concrete lintel — a horizontal support above the window — before he was released about 4.30pm. 
He was treated at the scene by NSW Ambulance paramedics and a CareFlight helicopter doctor before being taken by ambulance to Royal Prince Alfred Hospital. in a stable condition. Nearby homes at St Peters being demolished to make way for work on the WestConnex St Peters Interchange. Source: Supplied 
It is understood demolotion contractors were salvaging materials from the site when the 5-6 metre-long concrete window lintel fell, landing on the man’s legs and ankles. 
CareFlight’s rapid response rescue helicopter was called to St Peters at about 4pm, landing next to the accident site. 
CareFlight’s specialist doctor and paramedics provided treatment for pain while NSW Police Rescue crews safely extricated the man. 
The man suffered extensive bruising. 
A Sydney Motorway Corporation spokesman said the sub-contractor sustained a minor ankle injury which included some bruising during clearing work at the former Rudders Bond Store at the St Peters Interchange site. 
“Safety is our first priority and window removal work has stopped while SafeWork NSW undertake an inspection of the site today,” the spokesman said. 
“The contractor is carrying out an investigation into this incident.” Artists impression of the future WestConnex interchange at St Peters Source: Supplied 
The WestConnex Action group said that this incident comes after residents had been reporting, for a number of weeks, a series of alleged workplace health and safety breaches across a number of motorway construction and demolition sites. 
WAG spokeswoman Pauline Lockie called on Premier Gladys Berejiklian to urgently call a review of the project.
